Award.AbstractNarration:
Assembling the Tree of Life is a fundamental problem in biology that is providing insights into evolution, adaptation, and speciation. Much information about past evolutionary events can be inferred from the analysis of DNA sequence data collected from existing species. A notable feature of the evolution of molecular sequences is the significant role played by chance. In recent years, probability theory, the mathematical study of randomness, has provided key new insights in analyzing the power of statistical methods to reconstruct evolutionary processes in large-scale phylogenetics. The overall goal of this research project is to further investigate these connections. Through the development, analysis, implementation, and dissemination of algorithms for the alignment of molecular sequences and the reconstruction of evolutionary trees, this research will help advance the state of knowledge in evolutionary biology. The project aims to contribute to the numerous benefits to society of phylogenetic research such as the protection of ecosystems from invasive species, the identification of emerging diseases, and the prediction of disease outbreaks. Integration of research and education is a major component of this project. In addition to providing research training for graduate students, course materials will be developed in conjunction with the activities and made widely available.

In evolutionary biology, the speciation history of a group of organisms is represented graphically by a phylogeny, that is, a rooted tree whose leaves represent current species and whose branchings indicate past speciation events. Phylogenies are commonly estimated from molecular sequences collected from the species of interest. Despite breathtaking advances in sequencing technologies and the development of increasingly more powerful methods, phylogenetic reconstruction remains a challenging problem, and many evolutionary relationships continue to be the source of controversy. Most traditional phylogenetic reconstruction methods involve two steps: multiple sequence alignment and tree estimation. This two-step approach introduces systematic biases that can adversely affect the final tree estimate and other downstream analyses. The general objective of this project is to provide new mathematical insights on alignment methods and their effects on phylogenetic analyses as well as to develop new tools to analyze methodologies that go beyond the traditional two-step approach to phylogenetic reconstruction. This objective will be achieved by further developing the fruitful interface between probability theory and mathematical phylogenetics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Tree of Life is a visualization of evolutionary relationships between species which has found applications in evolutionary biology, viral epidemiology, and cancer studies, just to name a few. Reconstructing the Tree of Life, starting from genetic data, is a challenging data science problem. A key technical difficulty is the necessity to align genomes across different species, or otherwise devise reconstruction methods that avoid the alignment problem altogether. This project provided substantial new insights on the interactions between phylogeny reconstruction and sequence alignment, which are generally poorly understood from a theoretical point of view. Key outcomes are summarized next.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

Outcome 1: A standard alignment approach involves aligning alignments on a guide tree. From a mathematical perspective, that approach is closely related to the reconstruction of molecular sequences of ancestral species from contemporary data. Through the development of new ancestral state estimators accounting for nucleotide insertions and deletions on a taxon-rich phylogeny, a surprising mathematical result was derived: genomes can, in theory, be perfectly aligned even at arbitrary large evolutionary distances. These new results represent a first step towards a better understanding of the theoretical limits of multiple sequence alignment under relevant statistical models of evolution.

 

Outcome 2: A common alignment-free approach to phylogeny reconstruction compares word (or k-mer) frequencies across genomes to estimate evolutionary distances between species, which are in turn fed into a standard distance-based reconstruction method such as Neighbor-Joining. Under statistical models of sequence evolution accounting for nucleotide insertions and deletions, it was established that such methods suffer from severe theoretical limitations. Informally, they in general fail to succeed even when provided with unlimited data. 

 

Outcome 3: Connections to an important public health problem were further developed. Respondent-driven sampling is a widely used statistical methodology to study hard-to-reach populations. Building on the mathematical techniques developed in this project (specifically regarding ancestral sequence reconstruction on phylogenies), simple estimation strategies were devised and shown to be more accurate than standard approaches.

 

Broader Impacts

 

Outcome 4: Several graduate students and postdoctoral researchers were trained at the interdisciplinary interface of mathematics, computer science and biology.

 

Outcome 5: A new undergraduate course entitled Mathematical Methods in Data Science, which aims to integrate mathematical concepts, computational methods and data analysis with a wide variety of applications (including viral evolution), was developed at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Extensive educational materials, freely available on the course website, were created, including lecture notes, slides and interactive notebooks.
